responses_by_article.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
responses_by_article.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Value-based orientation models → Client-dictated pricing based on business value assessment (includes payment-based, product-based, usage-dependent categories)
Cost-based orientation models → Vendor-dictated pricing based on cost accounting (includes usage-independent, service-based categories)
Compact licensing models (57% of vendors) → Use few pricing components for simplicity
Value-focused models (28% of vendors) → Prefer value-based over cost-based components
Cost-focused models (15% of vendors) → Prefer cost-based over value-based components
Payment-focus models (47% of vendors) → Emphasize payment-based and usage-independent pricing
Usage-dependent models (33% of vendors) → Focus on usage-dependent pricing
Service-based models (20% of vendors) → Emphasize service-based pricing with complex licenses
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3: 'Layer 1 of our pricing framework consists of two types of pricing orientations, namely cost-based and value-based. Cost-based pricing implies that price levels of SaaS licenses are defined through cost accounting...cost-based pricing is dictated by SaaS vendors rather than clients. Conversely, value-based pricing of SaaS licenses means that price levels are determined through clients' assessment of the business value to be extracted from such software services. Value-based pricing is thus in sharp contrast to cost-based pricing in that it is dictated by clients rather than SaaS vendors' | Page 4: 'The largest cluster (C1) makes up 57% of our sample...most SaaS vendors prefer compact licensing models' | Page 4: 'Cluster two (C2) makes up 28% of our sample...vendors in C2 attach more importance on value-based rather than cost-based orientation' | Page 4: 'Cluster three (C3) makes up 15% of our sample...vendors in C3 attach more importance on cost-based rather than value-based orientation' | Page 4-5: 'Cluster one (C1) that makes up 47% of the sample represent vendors that attached more importance on pricing components from the payment-based and usage-independent based categories' | Page 5: 'Vendors in Cluster two (C2) that make up 33% of the sample attach more importance on pricing components from the usage-dependent based category' | Page 5: 'Vendors in Cluster three (C3) that makes up 20% of the sample attach more importance on pricing components from the service-based category'

responses_by_article.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
responses_by_article.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Pure-SaaS → Software that is simple to use with low/no customization requirements and lower strategic significance in customer business processes (e.g., office systems); uses time-based price discrimination for switching cost protection
Enterprise-SaaS → Complex software requiring support and integration with customer IT systems; higher strategic significance; uses labor-intensive implementation to create switching costs
Software Renting (Subscription) → Temporary usage rights with monthly/periodic fees; various pricing bases (user-based, usage-dependent, time-based, version-based, quantity-based)
Traditional Software Licensing → Perpetual license with full ownership rights for internal data center deployment; one-time purchase or concern license for unlimited internal use
Hybrid Model → Offering both rental and licensing options from same software architecture based on customer needs
Multi-tenant Architecture → Single instance serving multiple customers (tenants) on shared server
Multi-instance Architecture → Separate instances for each customer within shared hardware; enables customization in meta-data layer
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'SaaS providers can be classified into "pure-SaaS" and "enterprise-SaaS" business archetypes. Pure SaaS refers to software that is simple to use and has low or no requirements for customization... pure-SaaS products also have lower strategic significance in a customer's business processes compared to enterprise-SaaS products... Enterprise-SaaS, on the other hand, refers to software which is more complex and which may require support, involving integration with customers' existing IT systems' | Page 2: 'SaaS has multi-tenant or multi-instance architecture; the former refers to the situation in which a vendor hosts a single instance on a server that serves multiple customers (tenants), whereas the latter is related to the model in which a vendor hosts separate instances for each customer within shared hardware' | Page 5: 'Pure-SaaS providers (Firms A and B) seem to use time-based price discrimination to protect their business against low switching costs... enterprise-SaaS providers (Firms C and D) seem to protect their business against low switching costs by using separate pricing for the implementation work'

responses_by_article.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
responses_by_article.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Pure cloud/SaaS model → Initial approach focusing heavily (80%) on SaaS development with minimal on-premise maintenance; rapid transition strategy
Hybrid model → Balanced approach with 50/50 R&D allocation between SaaS and on-premise products; controlled transition allowing gradual adaptation
Three cloud delivery model levels → SaaS (software applications), PaaS (platform for development), IaaS (infrastructure and computing resources)
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1, Section 1: 'There are three commonly recognized delivery models of cloud computing, namely software-as-a service (SaaS)... platform-as-a-service (PaaS)... and infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS)' | Page 6, Section 5.2.1: 'ERP Co adjusted their research and development resources to 80% in SaaS and 20% in on-premise, as an attempt to facilitate the development of the SaaS products' | Page 6, Section 5.2.2: 'The resulting strategy is to pursue the so-called hybrid model where both ends (SaaS-based and on-premise products) were handled in equal terms. The distribution of R&D resources was adjusted to 50% each for SaaS products and on-premise products.' | Page 6, Section 5.2.2: 'The hybrid strategy led to so-called "controlled transition" towards cloud'

responses_by_article.article_title: Digital sustainable business models: Using digital technology to integrate ecological sustainability into the core of business models
responses_by_article.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Sustainable Software Solution (n=6) → Software platforms or layers to optimize ecological sustainability impact on customers' resource consumption and CO2 production; IT as outcome; eco-efficient or enabling

Sustainable Product-Service System (n=13) → Physical products enhanced by digital complements (mobile apps, IoT) to optimize ecological sustainability of product use; IT-mediated or IT-bearing; uses renewable energy and closed loops
Sustainability Intelligence (n=8) → Data analytics combined with sustainability science for transparency and sustainable decision-making; purely digital; IT ubiquitous; B2B only

Digital Sustainable Platform (n=4) → Multi-sided markets facilitating ecological sustainable value co-creation with complementors; purely digital; enables circularity, sufficiency, inclusive value creation; IT ubiquitous
IT role variations → Mediator (5), Outcome (16), Ubiquity (10) - based on Steininger (2019) classification
Eco-dimension variations → Efficient (7), Effective (12), Enabling (12)
Sustainability pattern variations → Resource optimization (19), Servitization (12), Closed loop (10), Renewables (15), Stewardship (24), Sufficiency (18), Inclusive value (12)
Differentiation strategy variations → Aikido (16), Breakthrough (22), Customer centricity (27), Open BM (14), Value network (12)

responses_by_article.article_title: When does a freemium business model lead to high performance? — A qualitative comparative analysis based on fuzzy Sets
responses_by_article.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Bundled Freemium Business Model → Business adds value through premium sales with bundled features; new product/service combinations; interrelated and reinforcing characteristics; difficult to separate high-quality functions; users often combine use of hypermodularity

Fragmented Freemium Business Model → Creates value with free products then adds many fragmented upsell products; diverse product features sold separately; users choose upsells by interests and willingness to pay; purchased products depleted after use; free products are complex and support modular purchases
Configuration H1 → Bundled + Fragmented + High Sensing + High Seizing (without Reconfiguring)
Configuration H2 → Bundled + Fragmented + High Sensing + High Seizing + Environmental Uncertainty (without Reconfiguring)
Configuration H3 → Fragmented + High Sensing + High Seizing + High Reconfiguring + Environmental Uncertainty (without/with Bundled)
Configuration H4 → Bundled + High Sensing (without Fragmented and Seizing)
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2, Section 1: 'We divide the freemium business model into bundled and fragmented business models' | Page 7, Table 3: Detailed definitions of bundled and fragmented characteristics | Page 9, Table 6: Shows four configurations (H1-H4) for achieving high performance with different combinations

responses_by_article.article_title: How Service Offerings and Operational Maturity Influence the Viability of Health Information Exchanges
responses_by_article.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Foundational Services Model → Focuses on basic EHR connectivity and health summaries exchange; suitable for early stages; attracts diverse customer segments; lower implementation complexity

Advanced Services Model → Includes e-prescribing, alerts to providers, clinical decision systems; requires deeper investments and workflow changes; appropriate for mature HIEs with evolved customer needs

Transaction-Based Revenue Model → Charges per unit of data/information exchanged (e.g., fee per laboratory report); suitable for early stages when service offerings are minimal; 'pay for what you get' approach

Subscription-Based Revenue Model → Levies recurring fee for specified volume of transactions per period (per-member per-month); ensures constant revenue stream; appropriate for established HIEs with higher transaction volumes

Hybrid Revenue Model → Combines transaction and subscription fees with differential pricing for different customer segments and service tiers; used by successful mature HIEs like HealthBridge (85% subscription, 15% premium services)
Grant-Funded Model → Relies on government grants and seed funding for initial operations; not sustainable long-term
Public-Private Partnership Model → Combines public funding with private sector participation; examples include DHIN and CORHIO
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 6: 'We explore the effect of this disaggregated notion of services for HIEs with qualitative examples from four HIEs, using a broad classification of foundational and advanced services. Because the primary function of an HIE is to provide capabilities related to digital data exchange... we classify EHR connectivity and health summaries as foundational services. Advanced services are those that require the HIE to make deeper investments and may necessitate substantial workflow changes, such as e-prescribing, alerts to providers, and clinical decision systems.' | Page 6: 'an HIE can monetize its services through two primary revenue models: (1) a transaction-based model, which involves charging a fee for a unit of data or information exchanged (e.g., a fee per laboratory report), and (2) a subscription-based model that levies a recurring fee for a specified volume of transactions per period.' | Page 10: 'HealthBridge has evolved to offer a hybrid approach... Currently, it does not charge any fees for clinician access to data and has designed a mix of subscription-based and transaction-based revenue models to achieve sustainability... HealthBridge earned approximately 85% of its operational revenues from subscription fees charged to health systems using the exchange, with the remaining 15% obtained from fees paid by users for premium electronic HIE services'

responses_by_article.article_title: Give Away Your Digital Services: Leveraging Big Data to Capture Value
responses_by_article.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Strategy 1: Enhanced Advertising → Uses customer data to target advertising messages contextually, making ads feel like answers to user needs rather than just selling eyeballs. Users still primarily targets for revenue.

Strategy 2: e-Ethnography → Uses user data internally to improve core products/services and understand customer behavior. Data is valuable by-product, not direct revenue source. Users become insight sources. Common in companies with physical products (Nike, Adidas).

Strategy 3: Data Trading → Directly sells anonymized aggregated user data to third parties (e.g., governments, researchers). Data itself is revenue-generating asset. Users are data sources and revenue sources. Available to fully digital companies and startups.

Transaction vs Nontransaction Markets → Transaction markets enable direct transactions between sides (e.g., eBay, Airbnb). Nontransaction markets offer product to one side and sell access to other (e.g., newspapers, Google ads).
Freemium Model → Mix of free basic services with paid premium features.
In-app Purchase Model → Free basic app with paid add-ons to enrich experience.
Cross-selling Model → Free service supporting physical product sales (e.g., Fitbit app with tracker)
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 5: 'Our analysis suggested three possible strategies for leveraging big data, which we've called enhanced advertising, e-ethnography, and data trading. These strategies may be seen as representing an evolution in the approach to big data' | Page 5-6: 'In enhanced advertising, users are still primarily eyeballs to be sold; the data simply make the advertising more targeted. Users are a target for revenue-generating activity... In the e-ethnography model, user data is still not a direct source of revenue, but it is used to support activities that generate revenues... In data trading, the data becomes a direct source of revenues, and users have moved from being a target of revenue-generating activity to a source of the data that generate revenues' | Page 3: 'In transaction markets, such as credit card payment systems, eBay, and Airbnb, the intermediary platform enables a transaction between the two sides. In nontransaction markets, the intermediary platform offers its core product or service to one group and then sells access to that group to the other side' | Page 3: 'freemium models, which mix free basic services with paid premium ones... in-app purchase models, which give the basic app away but offer users opportunities to enrich their experience with it through paid add-ons... cross-selling models, in which a company offers a free service that supports a physical product'

responses_by_article.article_title: Designing business models for cloud platforms
responses_by_article.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Development-focused platforms → Primary value proposition is providing environment for developers to develop, test and deploy applications easily (e.g., CloudBees RUN@Cloud). Application-centric platforms → Allow ISVs to develop extensions or add-ons for core application, third-party software only makes sense as add-on (e.g., Salesforce Force.com). Integration-oriented platforms → Focus on integration capabilities and connectivity (SOAP, HTTP, XML) to connect different systems (e.g., Dell Boomi). Distribution channel-based platforms → Cultivate online user communities and marketplaces where developers share, buy and sell (e.g., Google Apps Marketplace).
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3-4: 'four forms of PaaS solutions can be distinguished according to the core value proposition...First, development-oriented platforms such as CloudBees RUN@Cloud provide an environment for developers to develop, test and deploy their application easily...Second, application-centric platforms such as Salesforce Force.com allow ISVs to develop extensions or add-ons for the software firm's core application...The third form of PaaS focuses on the integration capabilities...Thus, integration-oriented PaaS such as Dell Boomi must have a variety of connectivity capabilities...PaaS solutions that offer strong distribution capabilities form the fourth form of PaaS; these platforms cultivate online user communities and marketplaces (e.g. Google Apps Marketplace)'

responses_by_article.article_title: Business Models for Cloud Computing: Experiences from Developing Modeling & Simulation as a Service Applications in Industry
responses_by_article.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Specialized one-stop-shop for a specific industry → Target well-defined industry with template-based applications, full customer support responsibility. Specialized one-stop-shop for a specific company → Restricted version for one targeted company only, may be financially viable for heavy end-users. Cloud extension to desktop/web-based simulation package → Extends existing simulation products with built-in cloud access via CSSP. Direct execution from CloudSME AppCenter → Uses AppCenter marketplace directly, quicker setup with fewer resources but less customization. PaaS provider business model → Platform provider model facilitating wide range of MSaaS business models for customers.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 6: 'During the discussions, five uses were identified each of which then served as the basis of a business model. These business models are as follows: 1. Specialized one-stop-shop for a specific industry 2. Specialized one-stop-shop for a specific company 3. Cloud extension to a desktop simulation package or a web-based simulation solution 4. Direct execution of the simulation software from the CloudSME AppCenter 5. The business model of the PaaS provider' | Page 6: 'In this model the CloudSME simulation platform customer, typically a simulation software vendor or a simulation consultancy, offers a specialized one-stop-shop MSaaS solution for simulation end-users' | Page 6: 'This model can be regarded as a special restricted and closed version of the first model, specialized one-stop-shop for a specific industry' | Page 7: 'In this scenario, the CSSP customer is a simulation software vendor who extends its desktop or web services simulation product with built-in cloud access via the CSSP'

responses_by_article.article_title: Towards a better Understanding of the Dynamics of Platform as a Service Business Models
responses_by_article.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Distribution Channel → Company opens ecosystem including customer base to external stakeholders
Application-based Integration → Platforms provide features to extend SaaS solutions
Development Platforms → Support entire application or service development process
Integration Platforms → Integrate combination of on-premise and on-demand applications and systems
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3, Section 4.2: 'The criterion core value proposition is used to describe the main platform offer. In addition to the three characteristics already identified by [33], we added fourth characteristic: (1) Distribution channel describes the case of a company opening its ecosystem including the customer base to external stakeholders. These stakeholders in turn will provide additional features to the ecosystem's existing customer base. (2) Application-based integration platforms provide features so as to extend SaaS solutions. (3) Platforms dedicated to supporting the entire application or service development process – including developing, testing, debugging, deploying, and versioning – are denoted simply as development platforms. (4) And finally, integration platforms integrate any combination of on-premise and on-demand applications as well as systems, and facilitate for instance the management of complex supply chains'
